Award.AwardTitle: Physics of Strong Disorder and Correlation
Award.AbstractNarration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education in condensed matter physics. The theoretical work takes its inspiration from experimental discovery in new materials and aims to explain and predict novel phenomena. Such novel phenomena often arise in materials where electrons are strongly interacting with each other, and this work will focus on this rich arena. Past examples include Nobel winning discoveries such as the fractional quantum Hall effect and high temperature superconductivity. The current project involves studies of a novel state of matter called quantum spin liquid, as well as the theory behind high temperature superconductivity. This research area is particularly well suited for the training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows because both mathematical sophistication and an understanding of real materials are required to make progress.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education in condensed matter physics. Strong correlation refers to physical phenomena in materials which are driven by the strong repulsive interactions between electrons. These phenomena include the origin of magnetism and a large class of insulators called Mott insulators. Recently there has been great interest in the study of a new phase of matter called the quantum spin liquid, where the tendency towards antiferromagnetic order is destroyed by quantum fluctuations. It is predicted theoretically that when this happens, novel excitations emerge which are not otherwise found in nature. Examples include fermionic particles carrying spin 1/2 but no charge and emergent gauge fields. Several candidate spin liquids have been discovered but their properties remain to be fully explored experimentally and theoretically. The project will carry out theoretical studies both to interpret existing data and to propose new experimental probes. Advances in the spin liquid problem have encouraged the P.I. to re-examine the long standing problem of high temperature superconductivity, which arises by adding carriers to a Mott insulator. The current project involves exploration of new ideas based on recent progress in the understanding of quantum spin liquids.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project deals with the behovior of solids when the electrons are strongly interacting with each other, an area oftened referred to as strong correlation physics. It is known that many novel phenomena owe their existence to this strong correlation. A prime example is high temperature superconductivty, particularly in the Cuprate compounds discovered in 1987. A main goal of this project is to elucidate the physics underlying the Cuprate superconductors. A second example is called quantum spin liquid. Often electrons are locallized by correlation and form local spin moments, which nomally form an anti-ferromagnetic state. In rare cases quantum frluctuation is so strong that the spins do not order, but form an new state of matter called the quantum spin liquid. This state of matter is expected to have exotice properties, such as particules that behave like elecrtrons except that they are striped of their charge and carry only spin.

We have made significant progress on both of these topics. In the Cuprate we proposed that a novel phenomenon, called pair density wave, is behind the many unusual properties observed in the Cuprate superconductors. We found that a single assumption is able to explain many experiments. This proposal receved a strong boost from recent experiments using scanning tunnelling microscope (STM) that found evidence of the pair denstity wave near the vortex crore in a magnetic field.

In the second topic, we proposed that a compound called 1T-TaS2 which has been studied for a long time is actually a rare exasmple of a quantum spin liquid that has escape our attention for 45 years. The compoud is known to have a lattice distortion that form clusters of 13 sites of Ta atoms. Each cluster captures a local spin moment, but there is no sign of order or even signature of the local moment. We proposed that this is because the local moments have formed a quantum spin liequid state. This proposal was recently confirmed by an experment measureing thermal conductivity down to very low temperature,. The experiment shows that the compound carries heat like a metal but no electrical charge, thus exhibiting the exotic particle mentioned above that carries spin entroy but no charge. We expect tht this wrok will open up new avenues of research and many new experiments will be carried out.
